comments.author: kittycat0876

comments.text:
I just watched ''Democracy Now'' online where Glen Greenwald was 
interviewed about his association with Ed Snowden and the latest 
revelations about the extent of surveillance and the diffuse nature of it.
For example, I didn't know that much of the state apparatus of surveillance 
is actually in the hands of private corporations. Just as much of the 
military presence in Iraq was that of private corporations like Blackwater. 
But these private corporate spy networks report back to government.
I also discovered what I had suspected from the beginning...The NSA and 
CIA  admit amongst themselves how they intend to use embarrassing, private 
website searches of ''suspects'' (that means anyone with political opinions 
they don't like) to smear them and discredit them as advocates for any 
political cause.
Basically  it means that if you go to a porn site that might embarrass you  
were it widely known, it can be used to discredit your views about 
political issues.
Blackmail basically.
And they're collecting information about all of us to cut us down if we 
ever dare challenge any injustice they decide to introduce now or in the 
future.
If this isn't totalitarianism, I don't know what is.
Oh and by the way, to the people in the American NSA and GCHQ in England, I 
have a message.....you think you're masters of this game, but one day it 
will be you or your kids on the receiving end of the nasty surveillance 
state that you helped create. .﻿

comments.author: JustinLeRoumain

comments.text:
@ ben I do marketing. The experience you encountered with your online 
shopping is called retargeting/remarketing. I won't go into it, but to 
answer your question about what we as Internet marketers do in relation to 
what the NSA does/did (in the context of tracking & data). If any public or 
private company did what the NSA did, that company would be breaking a lot 
of laws and you would be seeing top execs do some serious time. There are 
many privacy laws that govern the data & marketing sectors, laws that I 
guess don't apply to the government...or at least not the NSA....Please do 
not lump us marketers in the same group as the NSA, while creepy, our 
tracking is to help you get the best products, which definitely isn't the 
goal of the NSA.﻿

comments.text:
We’ve all read and heard much maligning and vilification of Edward Snowden, 
and some or much of it has had the “intended effect” of shaping the 
public’s opinion against this whistleblower to completely divert attention 
from the actual wrongdoers in this case: a governmental agency under the 
direct authority of the president of the United States, acting beyond the 
law and in violation of our Constitutional rights.
Have your views been shaped by what you’ve heard from or read by others to 
form an unfavorable or even hostile opinion toward Edward Snowden?
Are you sufficiently open-minded and fair to put that adverse opinion to 
the test of hearing an in-depth interview with Edward Snowden conducted in 
English by German television (NDR)?
If your answer is “yes,” then you will want to hear directly and in detail 
from the man himself at the link below.
Do test how fair and open-minded you actually are by accepting this 
challenge to hear the facts directly from the whistleblower himself . . . 
then form an opinion of what is really at stake and whether all of this is 
really about Edward Snowden or about an N.S.A./government spying scandal.
(JdeCP)
http://www.liveleak.com/view?i=f1d_1390839693#mUY9Qgt0Rts7VSPX.01﻿

+sokhoms You're advocating the government of a single country "lead the 
world" by spying on its population and hiding that fact from its citizens? 
Setting aside the very serious problems with nationalism and patriotism, 
don't forget that a country *is* the people, not a few elected government 
officials or organisations. A country hiding things from itself is 
dysfunctional by definition. A democracy (the US is purportedly still one) 
needs to be able to have informed discussions about how the country is 
being run, what laws are being passed, and so on, and this includes 
important topics like national security and certainly widespread, 
institutional surveillance of citizens. Hiding how these things are being 
done from the general populace makes that debate and dialogue impossible. 
This is just one reason why Snowden was so important.

I've made my points. You've chosen to not respond to any of them. I'll rest 
my case.

comments.text:
+Sokhom Sam I (and obviously other people here) would suggest you need to 
think about this more broadly. A reflexive reaction supporting NSA spying 
because it is somehow improving U.S. security is easy to buy into, but that 
effect hasn't been shown and there is no hard evidence that this kind of 
activity has had that impact. However the real concern is that this kind of 
activity raises deeper questions about privacy and associated ethical 
dilemmas, personal and group identity, freedom of expression, freedom to 
dissent and exercise civil disobedience, freedom to challenge the status 
quo, an open and trustworthy political system etc etc. These are the rights 
of a free and open society, and are directly challenged by the NSA 
activities that Snowden has shined a light on.

Doesn't it bother you that parts of these programs have been found to be 
"almost certainly" unconstitutional? Doesn't that concern you at all? If 
you're serious about protecting the US, I'd suggest you take breaches of 
the constitution seriously too - threats to the US aren't just external. I 
for one don't want my elected government spying on what I do. Not because I 
have anything to hide, but because I maintain that I have a right to 
privacy and freedom of expression without government meddling, oversight, 
or spying. I would be outraged to find someone doing this without my 
permission, no matter what the excuse.

I think it's fair to say that many, many people have arrived at a position 
that agrees that the NSA spying programs haven't actually done anything to 
improve national security. Big brother watching over all communications 
into and out of the US on the other hand has deep reaching consequences.

I'd suggest thinking about this more deeply. There are other incredibly 
damaging and far reaching consequences with allowing this kind of 
government activity. Don't just buy into the hype.
comments.author: snarkyboojum
